answers.explanation: The signal strength is 4/10 and 6/10 in OD and OS respectively. This OCT suggests there is a thin RNFL superiorly and inferiorly OU. This can be seen in the RNFL Thickness Map and RNFL Deviation Map – both of which are compared to normative data.

questions.title: Question 1
questions.text:
![](/content/media/glacoma3_1.webp)

Describe any pertinent findings from this first image.

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text:
The clinician then pulls up an OCT ONH and RNFL from 6 months prior, which showed the following:

![](/content/media/glacoma3_2.webp)

When comparing this OCT ONH/RNFL from 6 months ago to the OCT ONH/RNFL obtained today, what do you see is the same, and what do you see is different?

answers.explanation:
When we look at the RNFL Deviation Map, we notice that the OCT from today suggested a thin RNFL, whereas the OCT from 6 months ago did not and instead shows that the RNFL thickness are within normal ranges.

​However, when we look at RNFL Thickness Map (an objective measurement), we notice they are very similar to today’s OCT compared to the OCT from 6 months ago. The distribution and shape of the thickness (the yellow and red colours) in both eyes are consistent from 6 months ago compared to today.

​It may therefore be a good idea to look at the topography and the tomograms first to confirm correct segmentation and capture of the desired region.

answers.answerText: A. The OCT ONH/RNFL from 6 months ago was performed on an unreliable machine; the new OCT from today is more accurate.
B. These findings are due to a large mobile posterior vitreous detchment floater, which was picked up within the neuroretinal rim.
C. The incorrect date of birth has been entered in the OCT ONH/RNFL from today’s visit.
answers.explanation:
If you haven’t yet noticed – the date of birth in the OCT from today’s visit is entered incorrectly!

The patient’s correct date of birth is 07/18/1929 (entered in the OCT from 6 months ago) whereas the date of birth entered at today’s visit is 07/18/1999.

As mentioned previously, findings from any OCT ONH/RNFL are compared against age-matched controls to derive the “yellow” and “red” colours that indicate whether there is a thin RNFL compared to a “normal” person their age. As somebody’s RNFL naturally thins with age (roughly 2-4 microns per decade), it is important to compare patients against a normative value for their age. In this case, we were effectively comparing the OCT findings of an 89-year-old woman against a 19-year-old!

When the average RNFL thickness is coloured in yellow or red, this would indicate that this patient’s measurements are below 5% and below 1% respectively of their age-matched controls.

Note that this is the case for everything yellow and red except the topographical map, as the yellow and red colours indicate absolute RNFL thickness in terms of µm, not as a comparison to age-matched controls. Additionally, the RNFL circular tomogram is also not compared against age-matched controls.

Finally, although the signal strength is not ideal (4/10 and 6/10), the segmentation is good on the tomogram, indicating that poorer signal strength is not an issue.

answers.answerText: D. The findings today are due to poor signal strength and artefact and are nothing concerning.

questions.title: Question 4
questions.text: What group of people is the normative data for Zeiss Cirrus machines collected from?

answers.explanation:
Since the OCT from this clinical vignette was taken by a Carl Zeiss Cirrus machine, the patient’s results were compared to the Carl Zeiss Cirrus normative database, which consists of data from a 7-site study in the United States enrolling 284 subjects aged 19-84.(1) An ethnicity breakdown of the subjects reveals the subjects to be 43% Caucasians, 24% Asians, 18% African American, 12% Hispanic, 1% Indian, and 6% mixed ethnicity. The refractive error ranged from -12.00D to +8.00 D; high myopes were not included in the normative database.(1)(2)

There are other normative databases that are used for other OCT machines. Common databases include the Stratus normative database,(3) the Optovue RTVue database,(4) and the Heidelburg Spectralis database.(5)

It is important to note that although these databases attempted to include representation from a variety of ethnic backgrounds, they tend to include mostly Caucasian patients. Depending on the location you practice in and the diversity of your patient population, it may be important to consider this when interpreting results(6).

References:

1. Carl ZM Inc. 510(k) Summary Cirrus HD-OCT with Retinal Nerve Fiber Layer and Macular Normative Databases \[Internet]. 2009 May. Available from: https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/cdrh_docs/pdf8/K083291.pdf
2. Silverman AL, Hammel N, Khachatryan N, Sharpsten L, Medeiros FA, Girkin CA, et al. Diagnostic Accuracy of the Spectralis and Cirrus Reference Databases in Differentiating between Healthy and Early Glaucoma Eyes. Ophthalmology. 2016 Feb;123(2):408–14.
3. KIERNAN DF, HARIPRASAD SM. Normative Databases in SD-OCT: A Status Report. Retinal Physician \[Internet]. 2010 Apr 1; Available from: https://www.retinalphysician.com/issues/2010/april-2010/normative-databases-in-sd-oct-a-status-report
4. Optovue, Inc. 510(k) Summary RTVue with Normative Database \[Internet]. 2010 Sep. Available from: https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/cdrh_docs/pdf10/K101505.pdf
5. Heidelberg Engineering. 510(k) Summary Spectralis \[Internet]. 2016 May. Available from: https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/cdrh_docs/pdf15/K152205.pdf
6. Mehta N, Waheed NK. Diversity in optical coherence tomography normative databases: moving beyond race. Int J Retin Vitr. 2020 Dec;6(1):5.

title: Case 3
description: 89F presents for routine evaluation to screen for glaucoma
patientPresentation:
An 89-year-old woman presents for a routine evaluation of her eyes to screen for glaucoma. Her IOP is 15mmHg in both eyes on no glaucoma medication and she has an absence of any visual symptoms. She has no family history of glaucoma. Her past ocular history is unremarkable other than bilateral cataract extraction.
​
She receives an OCT ONH and RNFL of both her eyes. The results are shown below and compared with an OCT ONH and RNFL from 6 months prior.
footer:
### Learning Objectives:

1. Recognize the importance of checking date of birth on the OCT ONH/RNFL for all patients
2. Understand the database used to collect “normative” data as a reference in OCT analyses
3. Understand the importance of how age can affect findings on OCT ONH/RNFL
